quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: Your Agile team's velocity has dropped from 50 story points per sprint to 30 over the last three sprints. During retrospectives, team members mention they're struggling with the new cloud deployment tool that was recently mandated by the IT department. Several developers admit they don't fully understand how to use it.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What should you do FIRST as the project manager?

options.A: Hire a cloud deployment specialist to join the team
options.B: Arrange training on the cloud deployment tool for team members who need it
options.C: Escalate to the IT department to change the tool back to the old system
options.D: Accept the lower velocity as the new baseline and adjust project timelines

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Arrange training on the cloud deployment tool

insights.explanation: When team members lack skills or knowledge, the solution is training and coaching. This supports their development and improves performance.
insights.pmbokSupport: Project teams can thrive when members use appropriate skills that match stakeholder expectations

insights.explanation: You identified the issue through a KPI (velocity drop from 50 to 30). Now address the root cause revealed in retrospectives.

insights.explanation: Removing impediments means providing the tools, training, and support the team needs to succeed.
insights.pmbokSupport: Leaders focus on being transparent, behave unselfishly, and are able to ask for help

trapSection.explanation: Support doesn't mean replacing the team or giving up‚Äîit means equipping them to succeed.

trapTable.pmiValueBroken: Misses opportunity to grow current team members' capabilities

checklist: Is there a performance drop measurable by KPIs?
Did you identify the root cause (lack of skills/knowledge)?
Can training or coaching resolve the issue?
Will this support team growth and development?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Team member doesn't know how to do something ‚Üí Train them. Team member doesn't understand something ‚Üí Coach them. Always support growth.

coreFramework.frameworkName: S.T.A.R. Framework for Supporting Team Performance
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Supporting team performance isn't about micromanagement‚Äîit's about enabling success through measurement, support, and continuous improvement:

rows.action: Establish Key Performance Indicators to objectively measure team performance. Use metrics like velocity, quality, cycle time‚Äînot subjective feelings.
keyQuestions: What objective metrics measure team performance?
Agile: What's the team velocity? Sprint burndown?
Traditional: Are milestones on track? Quality metrics?
Are these KPIs agreed upon with the team?
rows.examKeywords: KPI, Metrics, Measure, Assess, Evaluate, Objective

rows.action: When performance issues arise, support growth through training and coaching. Give them the skills and knowledge they need.
keyQuestions: What specific skills or knowledge are lacking?
Do they need training (learn new skills)?
Do they need coaching (improve existing skills)?
Do they have the right tools and resources?
rows.examKeywords: Train, Coach, Develop, Support growth, Mentor, Teach

rows.action: Provide appropriate, timely feedback. Recognize what's working well. Address issues constructively. Create a safe environment for asking for help.
keyQuestions: What feedback have I given recently?
Can team members ask each other for help?

rows.action: After providing support, verify that performance actually improves. Check KPIs again. If not improving, take additional action. Continuous improvement.
keyQuestions: Are KPIs trending in the right direction?
If not improving, what else is needed?
What did we learn for next time?
rows.examKeywords: Verify, Validate, Continuous improvement, Retrospective, Lessons learned

training.when: Team member needs to LEARN a new skill they don't have
training.example: Doesn't know the new cloud tool ‚Üí Provide training course

coaching.when: Team member needs to IMPROVE an existing skill
coaching.example: Knows the tool but uses it inefficiently ‚Üí Provide 1-on-1 coaching

pmbokConnection.principle: Principle 3: Be a Diligent, Respectful, and Caring Steward
pmbokConnection.quote: Project teams can thrive when project team members use appropriate leadership traits, skills, and characteristics that match the specific needs and expectations of stakeholders. Knowing how to best communicate with or motivate people, or take action when required, can help improve project team performance.

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: **Measure:** KPIs (velocity, burndown, SPI/CPI) | **Support:** Train (new skills), Coach (improve existing) | **Feedback:** Recognize good + address issues | **Verify:** Did performance improve?
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: Team member doesn't know how ‚Üí Train them. Team member doesn't understand ‚Üí Coach them. Always measure objectively.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for: 'velocity dropped,' 'performance issues,' 'team struggling' ‚Üí Check KPIs ‚Üí Train/Coach ‚Üí Verify improvement. Never accept poor performance without action.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Principle 3: Be a Diligent, Respectful, and Caring Steward - Support team growth

secondScenario.title: üéØ Apply the S.T.A.R. Framework
secondScenario.intro: Now that you know the framework, let's apply it:
secondScenario.scenarioStory: You're managing a construction project. Your quality metrics (KPI) show that rework has increased from 5% to 18% over the last month. During a team meeting, you discover that two new subcontractors joined the team and aren't familiar with your quality standards and inspection procedures. The experienced team members have been too busy to help them.
secondScenario.question: Following the S.T.A.R. framework, what should you do NEXT?

options.A: Replace the two new subcontractors with more experienced ones
options.B: Organize a training session on quality standards and pair new subcontractors with experienced mentors for coaching
options.C: Lower the quality standards to accommodate the new team members' current skill level
options.D: Have experienced team members redo all work done by new subcontractors

quotes.text: We have to assess our team against some kind of KPI, key performance indicators. There has to be some kind of objective measurement that we can use. Not so much subjective, but something objective, something numerical, something that people can agree with.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Knowing how to best communicate with or motivate people, or take action when required, can help improve project team performance and manage obstacles to project success.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: The Exam Pattern: Train or Coach
fieldInsights.insight: Expect questions where 1-2 team members have issues. The answer is almost always: Train them (new skill) or Coach them (improve existing skill). Never: fire them, ignore the problem, or lower standards. PMI believes in developing people.

fieldInsights.title: Objective vs. Subjective Performance
fieldInsights.insight: Don't say 'they're doing well' or 'not doing well' based on feelings. Use KPIs: velocity, burndown, SPI, CPI, defect rates. Objective metrics let you have data-driven conversations and identify exactly what needs improvement.

fieldInsights.title: The Agile Support Model
fieldInsights.insight: In Agile, team members should be willing to ask each other for help when needed. That's the support model. Create psychological safety where asking for help is encouraged, not penalized. This is servant leadership in action.

questions.question: What KPIs do you currently use to measure your team's performance?

memoryPalace.title: üèîÔ∏è Memory Palace: The Mountain Training Camp
memoryPalace.intro: Remember S.T.A.R. with this vivid story:

story.title: Training Climbers for the Summit
story.narrative: You're running a mountain climbing training camp, supporting climbers to become **S.T.A.R.** mountaineers...

scenes.visual: üìä You SET UP the performance tracker at base camp
scenes.description: You track objective KPIs: altitude gain per day, oxygen efficiency, rope speed. Not 'I feel like they're climbing well'‚Äîreal numbers. You notice rope speed dropped from 15 meters/min to 10. That's your KPI alerting you to a problem.

scenes.visual: üéì You TRAIN climbers on rope technique
scenes.description: New climbers need TRAINING on proper knots and belay. Experienced climbers need COACHING to improve efficiency. You provide both. 'Climbers not knowing rope technique becomes frustrating and will slow down the team's ascent.'

scenes.visual: üí¨ You ACT by giving feedback during practice climbs
scenes.description: You recognize good performance: 'Great anchor placement, Marcus!' You give constructive feedback: 'Sarah, distribute weight more on your legs.' You create an environment where climbers can ask teammates for help without embarrassment.

scenes.visual: üîÑ You REVIEW the metrics after training
scenes.description: Rope speed is back up to 14 meters/min! The training worked. You VERIFY the improvement through your KPIs. If it hadn't improved, you'd take additional action. Continuous improvement for the summit.

story.moral: A great climbing instructor doesn't accept poor performance or replace climbers‚Äîthey **S**et KPIs, **T**rain/coach, **A**ct with feedback, and **R**eview results. That's how you support team performance on the mountain.

memoryPalace.selfTest: Close your eyes. Picture base camp. Can you see the instructor **S**etting up metrics, **T**raining rope technique, **A**cting with feedback, **R**eviewing the performance? That's S.T.A.R.
